align=left  In Portuguese, r- and -rr- have several possible pronunciations. In most dialects, it is a guttural r as in French ([ʀ], [ʁ] and [χ] in Portugal and Brazil, [x], [ɣ], [ħ], [h] and [ɦ] in Brazil), while in rural northern Portugal and southern Brazil it is a trilled r r (like in Galician). In some southern and western Brazilian dialects word final -r may be a tap (as in Portugal and Galicia), though English-like ɹ, ɻ or ɚ is more common, while in northern and eastern dialects it is guttural. In Spanish, r- and -rr- have kept their original pronunciation as an r. Intervocalic -r- is an alveolar tap in both languages ɾ.
